children.subject: CS 172 isnt often taught if you are interested in it, then this may be your only chance

history.content:
EE120 with Babak is the best class I've ever taken at Cal. He is one of the best lecturers in the EECS department, especially in EE. His lectures were constantly filled despite it being 2 hours. Workload wise, it's 7-8 homeworks (almost biweekly), 3 midterms in class (no finals), and a bunch of VERY good Juypter notebook labs. One of the jupyter notebook labs have you implement Shazam and how it works detecting and identifying music based on its frequency. 

From the standpoint of 16B, the only concepts you need to know briefly is continuous time vs discrete time, a little bit of feedback/stability, and a bit of DFT/fourier transform (aka phasor domain). Most of EE120 is taught from scratch but having some knowledge of these concepts makes the class really enjoyable.

------

For 172, I took it with Professor Sinclair, not sure about the professor teaching it next semester. It is a very enlightening class, you will really get to learn the basis for CS theory, and prove everything rigorously. With Sinclair, we got one homework a week, which was pretty manageable. And the problems were very good for understanding the material and really getting some experience applying the concepts. 

You mention computability. With Sinclair, I feel like this was the least emphasized part, since 70 actually does a pretty good job discussing it. You learn stuff a formally and come up with classifications for different levels of computability, but the class focuses more on automata and complexity theories. Proving that problems are NP-Complete or not is a pretty good taste of what the complexity part of the course is.

EE120 with Babak is the best class I've ever taken at Cal. He is one of the best lecturers in the EECS department, especially in EE. His lectures were constantly filled despite it being 2 hours. Workload wise, it's 7-8 homeworks (almost biweekly), 3 midterms in class (no finals), and a bunch of VERY good Juypter notebook labs. One of the jupyter notebook labs have you implement Shazam and how it works detecting and identifying music based on its frequency. 

From the standpoint of 16B, the only concepts you need to know briefly is continuous time vs discrete time, a little bit of feedback/stability, and a bit of DFT/fourier transform (aka phasor domain). Most of EE120 is taught from scratch but having some knowledge of these concepts makes the class really enjoyable.

children.subject: @Anon Poet super helpful and detailed, thank you so much! I will take them into consideration

history.content:
Hi, I know these two classes are vastly different, but how would you comment on and compare their workloads, associated with the professors teaching them, if I am similarly interested in both topics? For reference, I will have taken all lower divs, 126, 127, 170, and 189 by that time, and 120 will be my first EE class. For my background in the two classes, I didn't learn the signal processing part in 16B very well but found it very interesting. For the computability part, I found it makes more sense than a lot of algorithms taught in 170.

Thank you so much!
history.subject: CS 172 vs. EE 120
